page.title: 02Swallow Holes at Waterend
page.content: Footpaths North East from{Waterend } follow the line of the{Mimshall Brook, along which there are a number of {swallow holes.}A swallow hole is a bowl-shaped depression where surface water drains away, acting a bit like a plug hole in a bath or sink. During dry, rainless periods the swallow holes resemble small depressions; when the rain comes the water gradually drains away through the holes.In times of excessive rain, the swallow holes may not be able to cope with the flow immediately and a small lake may develop round about.The water will eventually drain away. The Mimshall Brook actually disappears under-ground at Waterend and it has been shown that it flows North under-ground and joins the{River Lea } at{Broxbourne. }
